Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bayesian State-Space Models for Behavioral Time Series Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will develop novel statistical models and inferential methods for the analysis of multi-domain behavioral data and time series with complex temporal and dependence structures. This research has the potential to advance the knowledge on the neural underpinnings of human and animal behavior. Neuroscience studies often involve the analysis and integration of data from different domains, such as behavioral and neural-derived data. The focus of this project will be on developing statistical methods for studying temporal data derived from functional magnetic resonance imagining (fMRI) and local field potentials, such as neural-derived brain signals. These methods also are applicable to other types of brain signals, such as electroencephalograms and magnetoencephalograms. These statistical approaches will integrate data from different domains and could be used by behavioral scientists to directly test for associations between decision making and brain response. The statistical tools that will be developed in this project are general and could be used to advance knowledge in other fields that collect temporal data with complex structure, such as sociology (network modeling), environmental sciences, linguistics, and signal processing.

The project will develop Bayesian state-space models for activation and connectivity in fMRI data. These models will be used to simultaneously estimate the hemodynamic behavior in local areas of the brain and to estimate inter-dependence between brain regions in a network, while taking into account variations across subjects and differences across experimental conditions. The Bayesian state-space models and related inferential tools then will be extended to consider associations between the neural-derived brain signals and behavioral data under the context of behavioral experiments. Bayesian state-space models for brain connectivity using electrophysiological signals also will be developed. To deal with high computational demands for inference resulting from increased model complexity and massive data, the methods will be implemented using parallel computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed new models and inferential methods for analysis of multi-domain behavioral data and time series with complex temporal and dependence structure. The project focused on the development, implementation, testing and application of statistical tools for analysis of functional magnetic resonance data and electroencephalogram data. Additional models and methods were developed and used for analysis of temporal data from global climate models and other environmental data. 

This project provided new Bayesian models for detecting activation and connectivity in magnitude-only fMRI data and complex-valued fMRI data recorded during single-subject and multi-subject task-related experiments. These models were used to simultaneously estimate the hemodynamic behavior in local areas of the brain and to estimate inter-depencence between brain regions in a network, while taking into account variations across subjects and differences across experimental conditions. Two main approaches were developed, namely, Bayesian regression models for complex-valued fMRI data and Bayesian tensor models for magnitude-only fMRI.  

In addition to the magnitude information provided by magnitude-only fMRI data, complex-valued fMRI data also provide phase information which can potentially lead to more accurate inference of brain activation and connectivity. However, there is a scarcity of sophisticated statistical approaches that can handle complex-valued fMRI data. This project developed Bayesian methods that combined the magnitude and phase information in complex-valued fMRI to provide more powerful and accurate detection of brain activation at the voxel level. These complex-valued models adequately incorporate local and non-local spatial structure typically present in fMRI data, and are computationally scalable. Further model extensions were also developed to incorporate co-activation and multi-subject effects. This approach was tested in extensive realistic simulation studies and also used to analyzed human complex-valued fMRI data from a finger tapping block-design experiment. The complex-valued models developed in this project led to more accurate results than those obtained using magnitude-only models. Software that implements the proposed models was developed and made publicly available.

Bayesian tensor regression mixed-effect models were also developed and implemented for joint inference of voxel-level activation and region-specific connectivity in multi-subject magnitude-only fMRI. One of the advantages of the tensor decomposition approach is that it accounts for the inherent spatial structure in fMRI data without having to explicitely build such structure in the statistical model, naturally providing dimension reduction and computational scalability. These models were used to analyze multi-subject data from a behavioral experiment. 

This project also provided educational, training, and mentoring opportunities to graduate students who developed research at the interface between statistics and neuroscience.
